subject: Re: Pluggable Selector considered harmful? (Re: [junit] Re: Observations from a production use of JUnit4)
msgSnippet: ... That s not exactly what I said.  I was simply pointing out that in order to make my code safer, I will always pick an approach that verifies A and B over
messageBody:
On 2/3/06, Jason Rogers <jacaetevha@...> wrote:
>
> > Code that uses both will always be safer than code that only uses one of
> > these.
> That is a very striking statement. Are you saying that (in your opinion)
> static languages are inherently safer than dynamic languages?


That's not exactly what I said. I was simply pointing out that in order to
make my code safer, I will always pick an approach that verifies A and B
over one that only verifies A. Seems to be simple common sense.

Having said that, your question made me wonder... It's pretty easy to come
up with examples of bugs that will be caught by the compiler but that might
slip through in a dynamic language.

I am trying to think of an opposite example, but right now, I'm coming up
empty, which tends to make me want to answer "yes" to your question. But
I'll think a bit more about it.

Very interesting question anyway.

--
Cédri


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
